Award.AwardTitle: Summer Program in Solid State Chemistry for Undergraduate Students and College Faculty
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Summer Program in Solid-State Chemistry for Undergraduate Students and College Faculty aims to increase the number and caliber of young chemists pursuing this field. The program begins with a one-week tutorial, held at the University of Oregon where student and faculty participants are immersed in the concepts and applications of solid state chemistry through a series of morning lectures and afternoon hands-on laboratories led by top scientists in the field. The tutorial includes two days focused on sophisticated chemical instrumentation to include microprobe and surface analysis techniques using equipment housed in the Center for Advanced Materials Characterization in Oregon. After the tutorials, the participants disperse to their assigned host laboratories across the country for an eight to nine week research session. At each host laboratory, the individual participant will become an active part of the research team, working on a project assigned by the host. This is also time the faculty participants can use to work on curricula to include at their home institutions. Participants return to Oregon after their research for a final symposium where they share their successes, frustrations and overall experiences with peers through presentations, a poster session and group discussions.

The Summer Program in Solid State Chemistry for Undergraduate Students and College Faculty has played a vital role in increasing the knowledge, membership and diversity of the solid-state chemistry community nationwide for the last two decades. The program begins with a one-week tutorial, held at the University of Oregon where student and faculty participants are immersed in the concepts and applications of solid-state chemistry. This is accomplished through a series of lectures and hands-on laboratory sessions using state of the art x-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy, electron microprobe analysis, scanning electron microscopy and surface analysis techniques led by top scientists in the field. After the tutorial, the participants disperse to their assigned host laboratories across the country for an eight to nine week research session where they become an active part of the host's research team, working on a project assigned by the host. This research experience gives students perspective both on the nature of graduate level research and the importance of solid-state chemistry to current science and technology. The intensive research experience is a critical factor that influences many undergraduates, including those from underrepresented populations, to continue their education by going to graduate school.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of the Summer Program in Solid State Chemistry were to introduce students to solid-state chemistry and to provide a graduate-level research experience to undergraduates – particularly those from PUIs – in order to increase the pool of graduate students with interests in materials chemistry. The program consisted of a week tutorial followed by nine weeks of research in host laboratories around the country. Project results were presented at a 2-day final symposium at which participants presented posters and PowerPoint presentations.  In response to student feedback, we updated the structure of the symposium each year. During our last symposium, each participant gave a 12-minute talk about his or her research. These presentations were grouped into 5 sessions based on similar research topic, chaired by an undergraduate researcher and each session allowed time for questions and general discussions.

During the period of support the number of applicants increased, leading to a pool of over 80 applicants in 2009 and 2010.  From these applicants, a diverse group of 57 students and 4 faculty members accepted offers of participation.  Approximately 30 laboratories committed to host summer research participants each year and submitted a one-page description of the proposed project. During the course of this project, ten papers with participants as co-authors were published in the peer reviewed literature.  Several hosts reported that they have publications in preparation that will include the summer research students as co-authors, but they were not yet ready at the time of this report.

Throughout the grant period, the faculty team continued to fine-tune the first week tutorial part of the program in response to feedback from participants, the host laboratories, and our graduate student and post-doctoral partners. We developed a packet with reading assignments in a solid state chemistry text, calculations used in synthesis and characterization techniques and procedures to prepare before the tutorial week in Oregon.  The pre-workshop packet lessened the differences between students’ readiness, as they were able to read and complete the problems on their own time in advance of the tutorial.  Hands-on exposure to solid-state characterization techniques were introduced in an inquiry-based format, where student teams chose techniques to apply to their prepared products with the goal of fully characterizing the materials they synthesized.  A number of senior graduate students and postdoctoral associates used this program to develop teaching skills as they prepared for future academic careers. Two of these individuals are currently assistant professors at primarily undergraduate institutions.

The goal of this program was to increase the number of undergraduate students that continue graduate studies in solid state and materials chemistry.  As reported by the project evaluator, the summer research experience in solid-state research increased the pool of students reporting that they plan to attend graduate school in the field of solid-state chemistry. As noted in our evaluator’s report of the first year of the program, roughly two-thirds of the participants responding to the survey had never taken a class with a strong emphasis on solid state or material chemistry. Eighty percent of the survey respondents reported that the summer experience was “very valuable” to them and 20 percent found the program “valuable”. All respondents believe that the program will be either “very helpful” or “helpful” in their future career choices. The reports obtained from the undergraduate student participants on their experiences were almost uniformly glowing.  Students’ comments at the end of the summer program make it clear that they were fully engaged...
